item.title: Restrict Item Groups per Warehouse
item.dc:creator: Ahmedyousef15
item.description:
Hello Frappe Community ,

I would like to share an app that I am currently building and get your feedback before publishing it on the Frappe Marketplace.

The Problem

In ERPNext today:

  • Item Groups are used only for classification

  • Warehouses are independent storage locations

  • There is no native way to enforce business rules such as:

    ‚ÄúOnly certain Item Groups are allowed in specific Warehouses‚Äù

This often leads to:

  • Wrong stock placement

  • Operational mistakes

  • Heavy dependence on user discipline

The Solution (New App)

I am building a new app that introduces Warehouse-based Item Group control.

Core idea:

  • Define rules per Warehouse

  • Each rule specifies which Item Groups are allowed

  • Enforcement happens on stock-impacting transactions

Supported transactions (server-side enforcement):

  • Stock Entry

  • Purchase Receipt

  • Delivery Note

  • Sales Invoice (when Update Stock = 1)

  • Purchase Invoice (when Update Stock = 1)

  • Stock Reconciliation

Design principles:

  • No core overrides

  • No Stock Ledger manipulation

  • Upgrade-safe

  • Marketplace-ready

  • Multi-company aware

If a Warehouse has no rule ‚Üí behavior remains unchanged (fully backward compatible).

Target Use Cases

  • Raw materials restricted to raw stores

  • Finished goods restricted to FG warehouses

  • Chemicals / hazardous items in controlled warehouses

  • Branch-specific warehouse policies

Marketplace Plan

I plan to publish this app on the Frappe Marketplace once:

  • The core logic is stable

  • Community feedback is incorporated

  • Edge cases are reviewed

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm posting here first

Feedback Requested

I would really appreciate your thoughts on:

  • The overall idea

  • Missing edge cases

  • Similar solutions you‚Äôve seen (if any)

  • Features you‚Äôd expect in v1 vs future versions

Contact

If you prefer a quick discussion, you can also reach me on WhatsApp:
Share on WhatsApp

(Feedback here on the forum is preferred so everyone can benefit.)

Thanks in advance
Looking forward to your input.

‚Äî Ahmed Yousef

item.title: üêû Bug: Same Serial No Allowed in One Stock Entry (Material Receipt) for Different Warehouses
item.dc:creator: Raj_47274
item.description:
ERPNext currently allows the same Serial No to be included multiple times in a single Stock Entry (Material Receipt) but linked to different Warehouses.
This behavior should not be possible ‚Äî a single serial number should always exist in one warehouse at a time, otherwise it corrupts the Serial No Ledger and creates data inconsistency across stock tracking reports.

Example Case

In my case, Stock Entry SE-HO-MR-00034 has two rows for the same Serial No BTCENTRAL00002 ‚Äî
one linked to ‚ÄúMehul Patel - PEPL‚Äù and another to ‚ÄúPanchmahal - Amul Amcs Main‚Äù.

Here‚Äôs the affected Serial No Ledger view

You can see both entries showing ‚ÄúActive‚Äù even though the same Serial No was used in two different warehouses in one transaction.

Impact

  • Serial No Ledger becomes inconsistent (duplicate rows for same Serial No)
  • Stock reconciliation reports become incorrect
  • Traceability and audit trail breaks for serialized items

Expected Behavior

ERPNext should restrict the same Serial No from being used more than once in a single Stock Entry, even across multiple child rows pointing to different Warehouses.

item.title: Stock Reconciliation performance and validation issues with large data (500+ warehouses, 20k+ rows)
item.dc:creator: Mansi
item.description:
Description

Stock Reconciliation in ERPNext becomes impractical in large implementations due to multiple issues:

  1. Performance Issue

    • Submitting a reconciliation with 5000+ items takes 10‚Äì15 minutes or more.
    • With 500+ warehouses, reconciliation files often exceed 20,000 rows, which the system cannot handle.
    • Browser becomes unresponsive and server requests time out.

  2. Error Handling Issue

    • If multiple rows are invalid, ERPNext validates them one by one.
    • After a long wait, only one error is displayed.
    • Users must fix one error, re-submit, wait again, and repeat ‚Üí very inefficient.

  3. Concurrency Limitation

    • Currently, only a single Stock Reconciliation can be submitted at a time.
    • This makes the process very lengthy for large datasets.

Steps to Reproduce

  1. Create a Stock Reconciliation with >5000 line items.
  2. Submit the document ‚Üí takes 10‚Äì15 minutes, sometimes fails.
  3. Add multiple invalid rows ‚Üí only one error is shown after long wait.
  4. Try to submit another reconciliation in parallel ‚Üí blocked or impractical.

Expected Behavior

  • ERPNext should efficiently handle large reconciliations (5000+ items, 20k+ rows).
  • All validation errors should be shown at once.
  • Multiple Stock Reconciliations should be processed reliably without excessive delays.

Actual Behavior

  • Submission takes 10‚Äì15 minutes or fails.
  • Only one error is shown after long validation.
  • Reconciliations cannot be managed efficiently when data is very large.

Impact

  • Go-live stock adjustments with hundreds of warehouses and thousands of SKUs are not feasible.
  • Users waste significant time fixing errors one by one.
  • Overall process becomes unmanageable in enterprise-scale scenarios.

Suggested Improvements

  • Handle large reconciliations via background jobs.
  • Split commits into batches instead of one huge transaction.
  • Optimize child table/grid rendering for 20k+ rows.
  • Change validation logic to show all errors in a single run.
  • Improve concurrency handling to allow large-scale stock reconciliations without blocking.

Additional Question:
For organizations with huge datasets (e.g., 500+ warehouses and 20,000+ opening stock rows), what is the recommended best practice to upload opening stock in ERPNext?

  • Stock Reconciliation struggles with large files (5,000+ rows).
  • Splitting warehouse-wise still results in thousands of rows and is hard to manage.
  • Is there another scalable recommended approach (e.g., Utility or background jobs, etc.) officially advised for enterprise-scale opening stock uploads?

item.source: Stock Reconciliation performance and validation issues with large data (500+ warehouses, 20k+ rows)
